{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3417180,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-21T18:09:56.400Z","cooked":"

So we plan on using robot vision next season on our robot, and having no experience I had some questions about photon vision, I have run it off my computer and got a picture to show up, but implementing it into the robot is a whole different story.

  1. What do you use to process the vision instead of the roborio, I saw some people saying they use a raspberry pi, which makes sense to me, but how would you make this happen? Do you connect the radio and the raspberry pi together?

  2. How many cameras do you use, I guess it depends on the game now that I’m thinking about it, but I’m just curious cause I know for Crescendo some teams used 4 cameras, also how many cameras could you use before something like a raspberry pi caps out?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-08-21T18:09:56.400Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":36,"reads":174,"readers_count":173,"score":239.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470114,"topic_slug":"questions-about-robot-vision","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/questions-about-robot-vision/470114/1","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3417183,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-21T18:27:06.319Z","cooked":"

  1. Teams use lots of different coprocessors, many of them similar to the raspberry pi. (The trendy one right now is the “Orange Pi”). The answer to how to connect them was more complicated last year, because the former radio only had 2 ethernet ports. You could just connect your RIO and your Pi to those 2 ports, but then you can’t connect to your robot over ethernet (which is the only way to do so off the field at competitions). So many teams would invest in an ethernet switch which splits 1 of the radio ports into many. The new radio we’ll be required to use next year, however, has plenty of ports, so a bridge is no longer required.

  2. The more cameras you have, the more apriltags you’ll be able to see at a time on average. However, with more than 1 you need to have some sort of technique for combining information from multiple cameras to figure out where the robot is. 1 camera will get you 90% the way there, pointed in the direction of your shooter or end-effector, able to help you aim in a game like crescendo or line up in a game like charged-up. 2 lets you see both sides of the robot which is nice if you want to align for intaking/autonomous and your intake is on another side. Teams using 4 do so to obtain 360 coverage. You’d have to ask them how worthwhile that was. Photonvision seems to be able to comfortably handle 2 cameras per coprocessor, but there’s a lot of factors.

docs.google.com

One thing to consider for general mindset on the topic: using a vision processing solution on a robot is one tool that helps you achieving new capabilities.

Spending some time thinking about what capability you want your robot to have is actually where I recommend starting - then, work backward to figure out what tools you need to get there, and to what extent a vision system fits in.

Some examples of capabilities might be:

  1. Automatically “last-mile” align to a scoring position
  2. Automatically turn and face a game piece
  3. Automatically drive from one side of the field to another
  4. Increase autonomous driving accuracy to (insert requirement here)
  5. Detect the presence of a gampiece in a location, and pick an autonomous routine based on that.
","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2024-08-21T19:29:38.897Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":114,"readers_count":113,"score":27.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470114,"topic_slug":"questions-about-robot-vision","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/questions-about-robot-vision/470114/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3417262,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-21T23:18:53.519Z","cooked":"
bathtubed:

Teams using 4 do so to obtain 360 coverage.

We used 4 LimeLIghts. When you consider camera field of view (width and height), obstructions, uneven lighting conditions (glare, shadows), motion blur, then we didn’t get 360 coverage but obviously a lot closer than with 2 cameras.

There are at least 2 profoundly different ways to use a camera. One is compute the pose of the robot on the field by knowing the robot’s position relative to any and all of the AprilTags (along with using odometry). Note that there are uncertainties in these calculations.

The other is essentially point at the target based on pointing a little bit offset from the very nearby AprilTag.

Cameras can also be used in a variety of ways to find game pieces.

Our rationale for having 4 cameras is we wanted 2 cameras - front and back - for intake and shooting and we always have backups for all of our equipment so we got 2 more cameras. Our objective was to get to World’s and we threw everything we had at it. There was no sense leaving perfectly good cameras in a box when we might get use of them on the robot. We got the experience as this was our first season for AplitTags.

As a general resource for vision in FRC, we have a pretty good presentaitipn we did for local teams on the theory behind and practical implementation of vision in frc. Its pretty detailed and covers much of what youd want to know plus some tips from our experiences with it.

Here’s the presentation: Computer Vision Workshop FINAL - Google Slides

(Answers to open ended speaker prompt questions are in the speaker notes)
